fields.descriptive_line: Stained and painted glass. Probably Flemish or Rhenish; mid 16thc. Representing St. James the Great.; STAINED GLASS; N, G, 16
fields.dimensions: Height: 159 cm framed; measured on sight, Width: 72 cm framed; measured on sight
fields.history_note:
Nominal File: MA/1B677

(21 August 1954) Letter from Percy Bates, Salisbury Art Dealer to Arthur Lane inviting him to come and see the glass.

(4 September 1954) Letter from Arthur Lane to Percy Bates:
…I came to Salisbury to see the two panels of German 16th century stained glass representing St. James the Greater and St. Vincent….May I ask whether the gentleman who owns the panels is prepared to sell them at that figure [£35]?...whether there is any further information about the provenance of the panels.

7 September 1954 Letter from Percy Bates to Arthur Lane:
Fortunately my customer Captain [?] of Newton House, Newton has been in today…He is quite willing to let you buy the panels for £35…As to the provenance of the panels, he could only tell me that he bought them in Belgium many years ago but has promised to try and search his memory for more details if any.

(14 October 1954) Note from Arthur Lane to T.R.:
…They are each 5 ft 3 in high x 2 ft 4 in wide, in wood frames. There are a number of loose pieces, and these should be stuck with gummed paper…

(9 November 1954) Note from Arthur Lane to Mr. Floud:
…and I mentioned that you would be interested in them for Circulation. May I hand them over to your for further action? The panels were acquired in Belgium and appear to date from the middle of the 16th century. They are presumably Flemish or Lower Rhenish. The inscriptions in both are modern restorations and there are a few other insertions of modern glass. Some modern unfired paint on the curtains in the corner should be cleaned off. The single figure represents St. James the Great; the figure of a deacon is probably St. Lawrence, who cured the sight of a blind paynim named Lucillius [?] in prison (Golden Legend, 1900, vol.IV, p.212).

Purchase form:
Circ.578 and 579-1954
